desc.size: Large tree, to 40 m tall, trunk diameter to 0.9 m. Trunk straight and persisting halfway or more into the crown. Crown dense, broad, and rounded with ascending branches.

part.partText: gray, deeply furrowed into rectangular plates.
thin, dark reddish brown, hairy when young; older branchlets may have corky wings.
dark smoky brown, 2 - 3 mm long, egg-shaped, slightly hairy.

alternate, long-stalked (leafstalk hairy), dark green, paler beneath, 5 - 8 cm long, 3 - 5 cm wide, broadly elliptical, base asymmetrical, tip short-pointed, margin doubly-toothed, rough above, soft-hairy beneath with tufts in vein axils. Leaves turning yellow and shedding in late autumn.
tightly clustered along twigs, dark red, 3 mm long.
single-seeded, winged (samara); short-stalked; 1 - 1.2 cm wide, round, flat, notched at the tip, hairless.

similarSpecies.comments: Ulmus procera is distinguished from the region’s native elms by having much smaller leaves (5 - 8 cm long). The samaras of U. americana have hairy margins. Ulmus pumila has smooth leaves that are not distinctly asymmetrical at the base or doubly-toothed. Ulmus rubra has very rough leaves, forked veins near the leaf margin, rusty-colored bud hairs, and brown, hairy seed cavities. Ulmus thomasii has corky wings on the twigs (U. procera may show corky wings on older twigs), leaves with a nearly symmetrical base, and hairy samaras. Characteristics of the hybrid U. x notha are intermediate of the two parents, U. pumila and U. rubra. The most distinctive features are the middle bud scales fringed with white hairs and the terminal scales fringed with reddish brown hairs. Celtis leaves, which are similar in appearance, have three main veins arising from the base of each blade.

speciesPage.habitatEcology: Ulmus procera is not known to have naturalized in the Chicago Region, but might be seen in moist soils along roadsides, forest borders, and thickets as an escape from cultivation.

notes.comments: Ulmus procera, brought here from Europe, was planted extensively in colonial times and has since escaped in more than a dozen states. Reproducing from suckers, it’s apparently a sterile species. This elm, as well as all native elm species, is susceptible to Dutch elm disease and phloem necrosis. See link to Dutch elm disease below.

etymology.comments: Ulmus is the Latin word for elm. Procera means tall.
